Situation1: They briefly mention their day during a casual conversation at home.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, phone pressed to my ear, my husband across from me, sipping his tea. He asked, “How was your day?” and I wanted to tell him about the stress, the endless calls, the rude customers. But just then, my work phone buzzed—an irate customer on the line, voice sharp and demanding, questioning every detail of the offer I’d just explained. My training echoed in my mind: stay calm, answer every objection, don’t let frustration show. But my husband was waiting, expecting me to share, to be open, to let him in. I felt pulled in two directions—one part of me wanting to close the laptop and talk honestly, the other needing to keep my professional mask on, to handle the customer with patience and clarity. My heart pounded as I tried to listen to both voices at once, feeling the weight of their expectations pressing in from both sides.
